text: very dramatic pictures emerging on TV as
well as on social media of hostages
being held so being held inside the
museum we understand the hostage
situation is still ongoing and that the
security forces have evacuated the
neighboring Parliament but it's unclear
what is happening at the Museum we also
understand that eight people as you said
have been killed seven of them were
foreigners probably tourists one of them
a Tunisian national probably a tour
guide who who were in the museum when
this attack started happening this
museum is one of the major tourist
attractions in this city it's a must
visit for most people who come to visit
the capital it has a collection of Roman
mosaics that's what it's incredibly well
known for and it's also very close to
Tunisian Parliament in a way both of
these buildings are connected and
they're on the same ground so it's a
place where tourists go to see these
artifacts I've been there a couple of
times myself it's as I said about two
minutes away from the Tunisian
Parliament and it's fairly easy to cross
from one building to the other building
I think it's important to remember that
this is the first terrorist attack of
this kind in a long time it's the first
time that civilians foreigners and
Tunisians have been killed in more than
10 years there has been terrorist
activity that all politicians from all
sides have been concerned about against
security forces here but so far no
civilian no tourists were attacked so
it's something that came up during the
election campaign last year and it was a
dominating issue in the last couple of
months and in fact the MPs were in
Parliament were discussing
anti-terrorist legislation that they
want to pass as soon as possible because
the Tunisian authorities entities in
public is quite concerned about the
reported numbers of Tunisians who are
said to be fighting in Syria who have
said - who are reported to have joined
terrorist organizations such as Isis as
well as the uh Nostra Front and they
also concerned about a possible flow of
jihadists from neighboring Libya ever
since and Isis presence has been
reported there so I think it's important
to remember that the borders between
Libya and Tunisia are quite open
crossover Tunisians and Libyans can
crossover without needing a visa so
these kind of issues have been discussed
here for a while and it's something that
only people have been quite concerned
about
